title: Venetian display serif in Runebound board game
content:
I'm trying to ID the serif face used for numbers on the cards in this board game. I believe it is also used for the titles on the cards, but not for the body text. I am sure I've seen this before, but don't know what it is. I'm guessing it's a "free font," the spacing doesn't look up to professional standards.

[http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/ffg\_content/Runebound/frozen\_wastes\_pr...](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/www.fantasyflightgames.com/ffg_content/Runebound/frozen_wastes_previews/princess_preview/princessicononrumorcards.png "http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/ffg\_content/Runebound/frozen\_wastes\_previews/princess\_preview/princessicononrumorcards.png")

Please excuse the artwork. :(  
 [http://chaos.corrupt.net/wp-content/uploads/2008/12/runebound\_redscorpio...](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/chaos.corrupt.net/wp-content/uploads/2008/12/runebound_redscorpion.jpg "http://chaos.corrupt.net/wp-content/uploads/2008/12/runebound\_redscorpion.jpg")

Homebrew card uses different number font, but right font for title:  
 [http://www.martsville.co.uk/images/RuneboundCustomCards/Soul%20Collector...](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/www.martsville.co.uk/images/RuneboundCustomCards/Soul%20Collector.jpg "http://www.martsville.co.uk/images/RuneboundCustomCards/Soul%20Collector.jpg")

Better images here, but may require registration:  
 [http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/556201?size=original](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/www.boardgamegeek.com/image/556201?size=original "http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/556201?size=original")  
 [http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/370179?size=original](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/www.boardgamegeek.com/image/370179?size=original "http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/370179?size=original")

Thanks,

T
author: Thomas Phinney

comments.content:
"Magic Cards" looks to have alphabetics identical to the display text, but the numbers are different (and really look like they were a different typeface to start with). I suspect that "Magic Cards" is something somebody threw together to match what started as two separate fonts....

[http://www.dafont.com/magic-cards.font](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/www.dafont.com/magic-cards.font "http://www.dafont.com/magic-cards.font")

So there might be some other font out there with the same letters but different numbers? Or are my numbers just from a different typeface?

T
I haven't had any luck finding it. Maybe Mike Gastin will...

I think I was only able to see three numbers (3, 4, 5). That's a tough ID chore. It would be easy to suggest similar alternatives, like [P22 Elven](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/sherwood/p22-elven/), but not so easy to spot the original without more numbers. It could come from a wide range of font styles.

- Mike Yanega

I've determined that the display text is Goudy Medieval. But the numbers are a different typeface, after all. Drats.

The last couple of links (which require registration, I know) show the numbers 0-5 at decent size. The 5 in particular is quite distinctive.

This is tough!

T

Hey Thomas,

My jaw was on the floor. No one had come up with [Goudy Mediaeval](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/richard_beatty/goudy_mediaeval/), in one of its lesser revivals, as a better match than “Magic Cards” for the title font. Even though, ostensibly, that is what the card designers used here. But, of course, you wanted a match for the numerals, so I didn’t chime in before you wisely tracked that one down.

Rest assured – I finally found those for you.

Before I get to that, though, I want to offer that the distinctive numerals in the set we had to work with are the _0_ and the _3_. All the others – including the _5_, albeit in condensed form and with a downward-pointing lower terminal – to a great degree emulate the structure of any [Old English](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/old-english/) font and its dozens of freely available knockoffs and derivatives who’s creators had no qualms about ripping off numerals. Just sayin’.

Without further ado: You’ll be hard pressed to find a more exact match than [Boere Tudor](http://web.archive.org/web/20100924174825/http:/www.sulucas.net/fonts.htm). Unless, of course, you can track down the designer of “the first Afrikaans family magazine, _Die Brandwag_” that inspired Su Lucas to create it!

_~ William Leverette_

Awesome. That will do nicely. Thank you, sir!

T
Just thought I'd chime in with my thanks! I'd asked Tom about this, but knew that identifying the font from just the numerals was going to be very, very difficult.
